title: 113_hr5648
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States-Jordan Defense Cooperation Act of 2014". Congress finds that the United States has provided significant funding to Jordan for Syrian refugees, with over 600,000 registered refugees and an estimated total of 1,400,000 refugees in the country. President Obama renewed a memorandum of understanding with Jordan in 2014 for assistance. The United States and Jordan have a history of cooperation, including a free-trade agreement in 2000 and granting Jordan major non-NATO ally status in 1996. Jordan faces challenges from the Syrian refugee crisis and ISIL. Jordan was a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council from 2014 to 2015. Defense cooperation with Jordan is crucial for US national security. The United States aims to enhance Jordan's status in law similar to other key allies for consideration of foreign military sales, crucial for national security. The United States aims to support Jordan in responding to the Syrian refugee crisis, combatting terrorist threats, and securing its borders. Congress supports expeditious consideration of defense sales to Jordan under the Arms Export Control Act. SEC. 5. AMENDMENTS TO ARMS EXPORT CONTROL ACT. The Arms Export Control Act is amended to include Jordan in various subsections, alongside New Zealand. The Arms Export Control Act is amended to include Jordan in subsection (h) and section 36, alongside New Zealand. The Arms Export Control Act is amended to include Jordan alongside New Zealand in various sections. SEC. 6 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to include Jordan. SEC. 7 authorizes the Secretary of State to enter into a Memorandum of Understanding with Jordan for increased military cooperation. SEC. 8 authorizes appropriations for the Foreign Military Financing Program. Amounts allocated for Jordan under the Foreign Military Financing program from 2015 to 2019 will be deposited into an interest-bearing account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. Withdrawals require authenticated instructions from the Defense Finance and Accounting Service. If the account is closed, the remaining balance will be transferred to the program's appropriations account. Interest accrued will not be used without approval from the Committees on Appropriations and Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives. Committees on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and Appropriations and Foreign Relations of the Senate are notified.
